name: Alyson G.
comment info:
Notice: I notice that the west coast barely has any development compared to the east coast. Places like Virginia and New Jersey are at the center of land development.
Wonder: I wonder how come Texas has so much land development compared to all of the other southern states. I also wonder how come North Dakota has a small, but significant for the northern central states.
Impact: I personally live in Virginia and in Virginia there seems to be a lot of land development. This affects me because it therefore means where I live is going to be more populated. More specifically, I live in Northern Virginia where it has more land development. This is important for where I live, because it means more people will be able to live there, which means more job opportunities. I view this in a positive way to increase employment in where I live.
Catchy Headline: "The Spread of Land Development in the US is the Spread of Progress"

name: Simon
comment info:
Notice: I notice that the east coast has had much more new land development in comparison to the western states. I also noticed that Texas had relatively large amounts of land development in a few parts of the state, while other parts of the state had little development.
Wonder: I wonder why Texas has larger amounts of development, compared to California, because although Texas is largely populated, California is the largest populated state by far. I also wonder whether or not a state's average income has an effect on the amount the state had developed over the past decade.
Impact: Since I live in Virginia, I will probably continue to notice lots of urbanization taking place, changing the area I live in from a somewhat suburb into a city-like area. As these developments take place, the population in the area will increase, and our community will likely witness large amounts of construction work, and many new buildings show up within the next few years.
Headline: "Eastern States Experience Widespread Amounts of Urbanization, Leaving the West behind"

name: Simon
comment info:
Notice: I notice that the east coast has had much more new land development in comparison to the western states. I also noticed that Texas had relatively large amounts of land development in a few parts of the state, while other parts of the state had little development.
Wonder: I wonder why Texas has larger amounts of development, compared to California, because although Texas is largely populated, California is the largest populated state by far. Impact: Since I live in Virginia, I will probably continue to notice lots of urbanization taking place, changing the area I live in from a somewhat suburb into a city-like area. As these developments take place, the population in the area will increase, and our community will likely witness large amounts of construction work, and many new buildings show up within the next few years.
Headline: "Eastern States Experience Widespread Amounts of Urbanization, Leaving the West behind"

name: Aayush
comment info:
One thing I noticed is more development is occurring in the southeast. This is from Texas to Florida. However, you barely see any development in the northwest and midwest. 

Something I wonder is why does the west coast not have as much development? In the past ten years, California has been developing and growing like crazy. In addition, Seattle itself is growing and becoming a secondary hub for the tech industry.

The impact which this has on my community is that Northern Virginia is progressing much more than other areas of the country. Northern Virginia is slowly transforming into a hub for the tech and finance industries.

I would say a catchy headline for this article would be, "Booming in the east? How the east coast is developing much faster than the west."

name: Anjali
comment info:
One major thing I noticed in the graph is that there is more development in the east coast compared to the west cost. However, Texas and Arizona have some major spots where there is more development. Development in the northwestern part of the United States is scarce though. 
      I wonder why California does not have as many major development spots since California has the biggest population of all the states in the U.S. I also wonder why there is so much development in the east coast compared to the west coast.
      This might impact my community because Northern Virginia might get an increase in development since Virginia is one of the states where development occurred. 
      One catchy deadline would be "Does the east coast have a spike in development compared to the west coast?

name: cc
comment info:
Notice: overall, there are more development on the east coast than on the west, but some of the western states like Texas, California, and some parts or Arizona are also very well developed. 
Wonder: I wonder why California isn't getting as much development and why texas is getting so much more development.
Impact: this impacts my community because my area is also getting increased development.
Headline: "Texas getting urbanized"

name: Inti
comment info:
I notice that there is a rather significant divide between the new land development in states east of the Mississippi river and that of states west of the Mississippi. Two clear outliers, however, are Texas and Arizona. Although they are both west of the Mississippi, they have had a noticeable amount of land development throughout their states. There are also a few pockets/clusters of land development in states such as Utah and North Dakota. 

I wonder why all of these trends exist. Why would the east coast be receiving so much more land development than the west? Why are there “random” clusters of development scattered in some western states? Is there some sort of correlation between this land development and some other variable?

Some impacts that this will have on me and my community are increased land development and urbanization. 

A few possible “catchy” headlines could be:

“The East Coast Has Hopped On The Land Development Train — And It Doesn’t Seem To Be Stopping”

“The West Coast Is Falling Behind On The Land Development Race As The East Coast Flies Ahead”

“They Say Everything Is Bigger In Texas — And Land Development Doesn’t Seem To Be An Exception”

“The East Coast Is Ahead Of The Game When It Comes To Land Development — Will It Keep It Up?”

name: Zhixuan
comment info: More development is on the east coast. After all, in history, the United States established a country on the east coast and then expanded to the west coast. In addition, the east coast is closer to Europe, and the Atlantic Ocean is much smaller than the Pacific Ocean, so the freight for trade will be lower.

name: Rebecca Cox
comment info:

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Rebecca Cox The red is for newly built houses, commercial buildings, etc. The reason there is so much red on the Eastern coast is due to trade. The Atlantic ocean is a lot smaller than the Pacific so Countries like England can get the trades over to the USA faster than sending ships through the Pacific Ocean. Also, America was founded in the East part of America so most of the population is located over in the East part of the US. The most populated states are known as, Texas, Florida, New York, and California. Some people could argue other states are also highly populated but those are the ones that are known the most as highly populated. As you can tell, most of those states are in the east. So that is why there is a bunch of red, why the red is mostly on the right side, why the red is neither good nor bad, and what the red is. The reason why it looks like blood is because of the locations of the renovations.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @edie The red is for newly built houses, commercial buildings, etc. The Eastern part of the country is more popular than the West so naturally the right side would have more renovations. For more read the reply on @Rebecca Cox's comment.

name: Moderator Greg
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of these graphs:  "Land Being Developed the United States. Where and Why?" by Elizabeth of Iowa and “Everyone's Headed East: Land Development Shows an Increase in the East and Barely Any in the West.” By Kerry of Chicago and "Spreading Out: New Land Development in the US" by Kaitlin of Massachusetts.

 

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back by Friday, March 19 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the map, and a few Stat Nuggets.

 

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).

View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 

graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 

Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex). 

 

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, whose city’s Seaport District is featured in the article, and Greg Yarnall of Morristown, New Jersey, who promises that there are undeveloped parts of the Garden State of NJ.

name: Kaitlin
comment info:
I noticed that most of the land development is taking place around the East Coast and the South. I wonder why that is. Is it due to the price of the land? Do land reservations and national parks also have an influence as to where new buildings can be constructed? Could it also be that these areas have reached a limit in construction and therefore can't have any more new land development? On the map, there seems to be rings of development. I wonder if this represents the expansion of cities already dense cities.  

This impacts me and my community because I live in Massachusetts, where there seems to be a lot of new land development. These developments can either benefit or harm these communities, affecting things such as pollution, the local economy, and the population. 

A headline could be, "Spreading Out: New Land Development in the US".

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Kaitlin 

Thanks for commenting today.  You mention 'rings of development' and I think that is very interesting.  We haven't had too many people comment on the patterns of development on the map.  What factors do you think create these shapes?  Are they near cities?  Along highways?  I'm curious about your thoughts.

name: Sarah Cruz AOSE
comment info:
I noticed that Texas is the state with more development  than the rest. I also noticed their is more development in the East and South coast compared to the West. Lastly, I notices dots that form in a circle around certain areas. 
I wonder if there are always more developments in Texas because  of how much land is available. I also wonder if this graph was made after the pandemic, how much it would change. Would there be more developments in the South or less?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Sarah Cruz AOSE --

You bring up a very interesting question.  This map only includes data up until 2019.  How do you think development will change after the pandemic?  This is a BIG question for cities, states and the country.

Think about economically, politically, financially, and environmentally?  (I bet there is more ways to examine the change.)  Is this a turning point in the country?  Which way will we turn?

name: Lauren Iskander
comment info:
What do you notice?
I notice that most of the land development that has occurred in the past decade has been concentrated in the eastern half of the United States. Additionally, there has been a lot of development in states such as Texas and parts of New Mexico and North Dakota. 

What do you wonder?
I wonder what type of land developments are considered in this graph. What is considered a "land development" and what is not? I wonder how much empty space is still available for new land developments in the upcoming decades. Are the land developments depicted on the graph taking place on new, open lands or are some of the developments taking place happening on land that has already been developed. 

What impact does this have on you and your community?
I live in a state that is extremely urban. In fact, my state is the most densely populated state in the country. Yet, there are many land developments depicted on the map in my state. These developments will have an impact on many people in my community and state as developments might cause traffic on roads or an excess of noise during the construction/development period.  

What’s going on in this map? Write a catchy headline that captures the map’s main idea.

Frederick Jackson Turner Believed the Frontier Closed in 1890. Over 100 Years Later, America's Land Development Has Not Ceased.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Lauren Iskander --

What do you think Frederick Jackson Turner would say now?  Maybe interview him (imaginary) and write a news article about what he says.  I’d be interested in reading it!

name: Lily Baker,AOSE
comment info:
In looking at this graph, I notice that the Northern and Eastern parts of the United States have a significantly higher number of land development from 2008-2019 compared to the Mid-West and West coast. I also notice how many land developments have occurred in the Southern states. I wonder why the South appears to be the part of the country where most land development has occurred. I wonder if this has anything to do with it is cheaper to live down south than living in the Northeast or California. Because the taxes are lower, most businesses would probably prefer to have a warehouse or factory down south than in more urban areas. This does not really impact my community other than the fact if more people keep moving to NJ, our state might get too crowded. Already in the past couple years, many parts of my town have been knocked down to build more housing. 
New Headline- "Where Are Most Americans Developing New Land?"

replies.comment info:

You bring up something that people have been seeing in very developed areas – the teardown.  Where has this happened in your area?  What type of properties have been torn down?  Have they been replaced with the same uses or other uses?  What has been the reaction to tear downs?  Have there been political (voting or regulations) reactions?

name: Brooke, Elle, Rose, Sarah
comment info: After analyzing the graph, our group noticed several things such as the East and South Coast have more land development than the West Coast. We also noticed that Texas has the largest red dots in a cluster, while states like Nevada, Wyoming, Montana, South Dakota, Oregon, and Nebraska, have had less land development over the years. In addition, we noticed that the population of a city does not really coincide with the new development in certain areas in the United States. The last thing we noticed was that some clusters of land development made a circular shape around the city that they were in. After making observations, our group had some questions about the graph like why there is more development in the East compared to the West. Another thing we wondered was what kind of land development they are referring to, public business areas or more private residential areas. We also wondered why Texas had so many concentrated areas of red dots. This impacts our community positively because the more developed a location has, the more opportunities for people and the more people come there to visit which grows that location a lot. Lastly, this impacts our community negatively because it means that forests and trees could be destroyed to make room for new development such as apartment buildings, houses, or roads. A catchy headline for this graph is “New Development in the United States."

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Brooke, Elle, Rose, Sarah --

Very interesting noticings and wonderings about the map.  What did you do to come up with so many comments?

What do you  mean by “we noticed that the population of a city does not really coincide with the new development in certain areas in the United States?”  Please share with us evidence from the graph.

You notice the clusters around cities.  If the rings are beyond the cities and their suburbs, they are called “exurbs.”  Do you have exurbs in the Twin Cities?  How do exurbs affect the Twin Cities?

Great pros and cons of development.  Can you give an example of each from where you live?

replies.name: J
replies.comment info:
@Brooke, Elle, Rose, Sarah

I agree the more development of a new location in the states the more opportunity for jobs, opportunities, establishing home etc. I wonder if population is a factor that contributes to developing new land?

name: Sara Warren
comment info:
Sprawling across America: The increasing size of our cities
We notice that new land has developed a lot where there are big cities and a large population. Also, the east coast tends to have more development than the rest of the country. The midwest has the least amount of development. Oregon looks like it has the least amount of development. Although Connecticut is small it does look like it has the most development. Texas development is very condensed in some areas but in the rest very condensed. Most states have either very condensed areas only in certain spots or are not very condensed but have small spots all over. We wonder how much more previously natural we have destroyed before 2008. I wonder why there is more land development in smaller states rather than larger ones. This impacts us in many ways, for example, since this map shows how urban sprawl is leading to increasingly large metropolitan areas, this could negatively impact our community by getting rid of wildlife areas and replacing them with man-made structures.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Sara Warren --

Great headline!  But, do you see evidence of development outside of cities?

All of this development is in your lifetime – 2008 - 2019.  How about commenting about development in Minnesota or even the greater Twin Cities, where you live?  What have you seen – development on land that had not previously been developed or redevelopment of land that had already been built?  How has this affected Minnesota as well as you and your community?

replies.name: L
replies.comment info:
@Sara Warren 
Very good point on why bigger states appear to be less popular with land development vs smaller states. The continuous getting rid of wildlife areas is definitely a huge issue and does seem to be getting better as we modernize.

name: Grace U, Kaitlin B, Evan D, Brian S
comment info: In the data provided by the graph, our group found several things that caught our interest. First, we noticed much of the new development has taken place around major cities. While the urban areas in cities remain the same, developments are created in suburban areas surrounding the cities. A lot of new developments have occurred in some of the most populated states, such as Texas, California, and Florida. We also noticed that many of the new developments are concentrated in one specific area rather than being spread throughout a state. In Minnesota, the development was centered around the Twin Cities - we wonder if most of the development in other states are around major cities as well? Additionally, what is going around in the western area of North Dakota and why is so much development taking place there? We also found that there was not a lot of recent development in Maine? Are property taxes too high? What would cause private or public contractors to build elsewhere? Based on these new developments, this impacts both us and our community as new development is important for creating opportunities and providing for an expanding population. As development continues across the country, it is important that investments are made in states where new infrastructure is direly needed. We would title this headline, “As the U.S. Population Expands, so do the Nation’s Cities.”

name: Group 1(EROH)
comment info: This graph shows the amount of new land development across the continental United States. Based on the graph, our group noticed that there seems to be a fair bit more development on the eastern side of the United States. The west has only a few regions with a lot of development, and there is a fair bit of empty area. Our group was surprised with how much area lacked any new development throughout the entire country. Our group wonders about the effectiveness of this graph and others like it. The areas of density on these types of maps are all generally quite similar to a population map. Comparing this map to a population map you can pinpoint all the big cities and densely populated places in the same areas where new development is occurring. More people will simply increase the number of data points in that area. Despite this graphs like these still have a purpose for the community. For one it allows us where new construction would be likely to occur, which may affect our interest in moving to a particular area.

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Group 1(EROH) I agree

HI, Group 1(EROH) --

“The areas of density on these types of maps are all generally quite similar to a population map.”  WOW!  Great observation.

Would you share some examples of where this is true?  But, also, what higher population areas is there little development, even in your state.  And, what low population areas is there major development?

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Group 1(EROH) I agree that is it interesting that a lot of the country has none or very little new land development.

Why is there less development happening as you look west on the map, and more happening when you look towards the east? Why does development occur around large cities and not in it as much. This map is showing where people are living, and where new housing, apartments and buildings are being built. So people are naturally going to move there a lot more than they would have previously. “Which area is land developing the fastest?”

replies.name: S

name: Karah, Emma T, Ian B
comment info:
Title: Which states are developing the fastest? 
We notice that a lot of new land development happens around big cities. There is a large area of the east coast that has a lot of new land development. We also notice that the land development areas tend to be really condensed in one area. One state with lots of land development is Texas.
We wonder why the east seems to have more new land development vs the west and why are some of the newer land developments even necessary…? Also, we wonder if maybe there might be a relation between the number of people who develop new land and the population of people in the United States? The impact that we are seeing is that many suburbs are being developed right now. There are a lot of rings on this map, and that shows that inner city land is not being developed right now. Instead, there is a ton of work being done in the suburbs. Expanding metropolitan areas are very common right now as shown in this graph.

name: Alex
comment info:
Group 4: Mandi, Sabrina, Alex and Emma 
We notice that a lot of the new land development is occurring in the eastern side of the United 
States. In addition to this, we also notice that a lot of it is taking place in the major cities of each state. Lastly, we also noticed that there is major land development in Texas and New Jersey.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s map shows the land that was newly developed from 2008 to 2019.  Data was derived by a computer model using satellite imagery.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and “What impact does this topic have on you and your community?”

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in this map. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the article that included this map and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

Keep noticing and wondering.  The next graph on vaccine roadblocks will be released by Friday, March 19 with moderation on Wednesday, March 24.

name: Emely
comment info:
What do you notice?
- Things that I notice are that the East and South Coast area has more land development than the West Coast. Most of the marks are being placed in certain areas of the state instead of the whole place, therefore it can mean that certain areas within the state have the ability to do this or the space to have this land develop more.
What do you wonder?
- What I wonder is what is causing this land development and why is it mainly in the east? Could it be because these areas are creating more housing/residential areas due to the pandemic, trying to house people as much as they can. Is this business-wise? as these places being made in order to expand businesses or create more? Do the red marks have a greater significance than the lighter markers?
What impact does this have on you and your community?
- The impact this has on me and my community is having us wonder if these changes in my state are going to be physically seen. As shown on the map, there seems to be a huge smudge or red on Massachusetts, are these changes business-wise? Are the changes for the community and for the better? It's having us come up with a lot of questions about the changes.
What’s going on in this map? Write a catchy headline that captures the map’s main idea.
Headline: Hey! What's new with land development in the 50 states? Find out for yourself!

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Emely --

You are right – the places that are being developed have more space.  That’s because of supply (of land).  But, the development may be occurring there because people and companies want to be there.  That’s because of demand (by users).  

Pick a region or city that is being developed because of supply.  Pick a region or city that is being developed because of demand.  Which drives Massachusetts – supply or demand?  What’s happening in your community?   Please share with us your thoughts.

name: Eliana
comment info:
What do you notice?
The East Side of the map has much more red than the rest 

What do you wonder?
What this land development is for and why there’s more in a certain area

What impact does this have on you and your community?
the developments may be for public uses in My community but it’s not a direct impact. Can be used for homes or facilities near..

What’s going on in this map? Write a catchy headline that captures the map’s main idea.
New land in the US

replies.comment info:
HI, @Eliana --

Welcome back.  You are terrific member of the What’s Going On In This Graph? community.

You may want to read the paragraph below the map.  It will give you more information about what the graph is showing.  

For your community, have you seen new development?  Has it been on vacant land or has something been torn down and there is now new development?  If the latter is the case, does the new development have the same use or a new use?  Why do you think this has happened?

Please share your observations with us.

name: Ava
comment info:
What I notice:
- The most land development is more in the East Coast than the West Coast
- Most of the developments are in concentrated areas rather than all around the state
- Texas has more concentrated area’s than other states

What I wonder:
* Why is there more development in the East Coast than the West?
* Texas probably has the most concentrated developments, is it for commercial or residential?
* Does the East Coast population growing so there needs to be more development?
* What do the dark reds and the more lighter reds mean?
It impacts my community because if WA doesn’t have that much  land development, could we be having less population?

A headline could be: Reds and white areas, what’s the difference?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ava --

Good wonder – what do the dark red areas mean?  I’m thinking that dark red just represents more red dots closer together.  What do you think?

You talk about the relationship between development and growth of population.  When I think about growth of population, I think about the U.S. Census.  Since all of this development was from 2008-2019, the change in the population would be recognized in the 2020 Census.  And, the Census is used to determine the number of members of the House of Representative by state.  How could this development change political representation?  (Of course, the development does not have to be residential.  How would commercial or recreational uses affect political representation?)  How could this affect the State of Washington?

HI, @Ava --

So many people are noticing that there seems to be more development on the East Coast and Texas than anywhere else.  Why do think this is so for the East Coast?  Is the reason the same of different for Texas?

In my reply to your “state mate” Ava, I ask about how these changes in development may affect national political representation.  What do you think?  I know we in Massachusetts are thinking about it as we will probably lose a Representative due to the 2020 U.S. Census count.

name: Sophie
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
I notice that most of the land development is in and around large cities. There was a lot of land development in Texas cities, however, in California cities, there was not nearly as much development. I also notice that there is a lot of land development on the east coast in a cluster towards New England. while the west coast has much less development. 

2. What do you wonder?
I wonder why the red is almost encircling large cities and isn't filled in. They almost look like small craters, with no development in the centers. 

3. What impact does this have on you and your community?
There is a lot of red near where I live in Massachusetts, which I find very interesting because I live near Lowell, which is a city, but I didn't realize they had so much development they would be a bright red. 

4. What's going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.
"Is your city being developed?"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Sophie --

You “wonder why the red is almost encircling large cities and isn't filled in. They almost look like small craters, with no development in the centers.”  Think about it – “no development in the centers?”  Or, is something else going on?

You wonder about where all of this development is near where you live.  Maybe drive around Lowell.  Do you see new development since 2008?  Maybe it has been going on and you haven’t realized it.  This impression happen to many people.  That’s why this map from satellite images is so surprising!

name: Mia
comment info:
What I notice: 
1. I notice that there is land development in pretty much everywhere in the United States. Some or less than others, but they all have at least the tiniest bit of land development. 
2. It looks like the East and South coast have more red(which means more land development) than the West coast. 
3. It looks like Texas has the most red part. Or you can say it has lots of new land development.
What I wonder: 
1. I wonder why some places have less land development than other places. Why do some places have less land development than others?
2. What kind of land development is it? 
3. Is it private or public? 
How does it impact my community:
It impacts my community because it shows me how much land development is going on in MY state. My community has less than Texas, but it still has some.
Catchy Headline: 
US Land Development: How much land development do you have?

name: demi
comment info:

name: Joseph Mendoza
comment info: I notice that this is a map which tells us where new land has developed in the continental Untied States in the past decade. The blotches of red are areas where land was developed for homes, commercial centers, large buildings, and other facilities. I also notice that there is less land development in the west while there is more in the east. I wonder as to why is it that we see more land development in the east and not the west. This is because the west is notorious for having so much space and less developed land, so I would like to know why there is more development in the east if this area is already pretty condensed and immensely developed. This impacts my community in the sense that I live in the Northeast, and I worry that there will be too much development in my area. With land development comes more people, so it makes me a little anxious that my community may become very overpopulated. I know that in California, specifically L.A, there already is a lot of people there and the air quality is not  so healthy. Hopefully the same does not happen here. Potential catchy headline: "How Does Land Development Impact Your Future?"

You mention “new land development.” I want to make sure that you realize that some of this development is on land that has never been developed and some of it requires tearing down something and building a new development.

name: Elizabeth
comment info:
I notice that the development doesn't necessarily coincide with major cities, this is where I figured the most development would be. Immediately Texas sticks out to me because it seems to have the most development at the moment.  
I wonder why Texas has so much development? Arizona also has a large spot of development. What is different in these states versus say California or New York? I would think these states would have had more need to development. 
I live in Iowa where we seem to have a dense spot in the center. Perhaps Des Moines area?
"New Land Being Developed the United States. Where and Why?"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Elizabeth --

Your headline asks “Where and Why” there is new development.  I bet there are many reasons.  

Development may occur because of supply (of land).  But, the development may be occurring there because people and companies want to be there.  That’s because of demand (by users).  

Pick a region or city that is being developed because of supply.  Pick a region or city that is being developed because of demand.  Which drives Des Moines – supply or demand?  What’s happening in your community?   

Please share with us your thoughts.

comment info:

I also wonder why there seems to be a lot of development in western North Dakota, as the population density seems to be awfully small.
